title: Glasgow-Imrie Criteria for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis
description: Clinical scoring system to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis using 8 laboratory and clinical parameters. Helps predict mortality risk and guide management decisions including ICU admission and treatment intensity. Uses the PANCREAS mnemonic for easy recall.

parameters.name: pao2
parameters.description: Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) in mmHg from arterial blood gas

parameters.name: wbc
parameters.description: White blood cell count (neutrophil count) in cells × 10⁹/L

parameters.name: urea
parameters.description: Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level in mg/dL

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for severe pancreatitis (7-16% risk). Typically managed with conservative treatment on general ward. Monitor for clinical deterioration. Consider oral feeding when tolerated.
Moderate risk for severe pancreatitis (20-61% risk). Consider ICU monitoring or high-dependency unit. Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain management, and close monitoring for complications required.
High risk for severe pancreatitis (55-100% risk). ICU admission typically required. Aggressive supportive care, monitor for organ failure and local complications. May require surgical intervention.

references: Imrie CW, Benjamin IS, Ferguson JC, et al. A single-centre double-blind trial of Trasylol therapy in primary acute pancreatitis. Br J Surg. 1978;65(5):337-341.
Blamey SL, Imrie CW, O'Neill J, Gilmour WH, Carter DC. Prognostic factors in acute pancreatitis. Gut. 1984;25(12):1340-1346. doi: 10.1136/gut.25.12.1340.
Ranson JH, Rifkind KM, Roses DF, Fink SD, Eng K, Spencer FC. Prognostic signs and the role of operative management in acute pancreatitis. Surg Gynecol Obstet. 1974;139(1):69-81.

Banks PA, Bollen TL, Dervenis C, et al. Classification of acute pancreatitis--2012: revision of the Atlanta classification and definitions by international consensus. Gut. 2013;62(1):102-111. doi: 10.1136/gutjnl-2012-302779.
formula: Glasgow-Imrie Score = Sum of positive criteria: PaO2 <59.3 mmHg (1 point) + Age >55 years (1 point) + WBC >15×10⁹/L (1 point) + Calcium <8 mg/dL (1 point) + Urea >44.8 mg/dL (1 point) + LDH >600 IU/L (1 point) + Albumin <3.2 g/dL (1 point) + Glucose >180 mg/dL (1 point)
notes: Originally developed as modification of Ranson's criteria for acute pancreatitis
Uses PANCREAS mnemonic: PaO2, Age, Neutrophils, Calcium, Renal function, Enzymes, Albumin, Sugar
Should be assessed within 48 hours of admission for accurate prognostication
Score ≥3 indicates significant likelihood of severe pancreatitis
More than 3 positive criteria may require ICU transfer
Developed in 1980s, predating modern pancreatitis management guidelines
Comparable predictive accuracy to Ranson's criteria
Does not include imaging findings (unlike modern severity scores)
Should be used in conjunction with clinical assessment and imaging
APACHE II score may be more useful for daily monitoring
Consider modern scoring systems like BISAP or SIRS for additional assessment
Not recommended as sole determinant for surgical intervention
Mortality risk correlates with score but also depends on age and comorbidities
Early identification of severe cases allows for appropriate resource allocation
